theory.intro: <par>Solving an equation is often done in two steps: first you clean up the equation, and then you solve this cleaned-up equation according to a fixed plan. The "cleaning up" part is what we practice in this skill. To be precise, our goal is to reduce every equation (where possible) to a certain <term>standard form</term>.</par>

When this is the case for our equation - the right-hand side is zero and the left-hand side is a polynomial - then the equation is in a standard form.</par>

theory.normalization: <head>To normalize or not to normalize</head><par>Note that our equation satisfies the conditions we set. However, we can still divide it by <inline-math/> to get <block-math/> That is, we ensure that the highest power of <inline-math/> has no number (well, technically the number <inline-math/>) in front of it. When we do this, we <term>normalize</term> the equation.</par><par>But which form is cleaner? Mathematicians have different opinions here. Some argue that the first form is cleaner, since it has no fraction at all, even for the numbers. Others argue that the second normalized version is cleaner. After all, there are infinitely many versions of the equation that meet our requirements (we can multiply it by any number) but there is only one version where the highest power of <inline-math/> has no number in front of it. It is unique!</par><par>In practice, it really depends on the situation what is more convenient. Sometimes you want to normalize the equation, and sometimes it is easier to get rid of any potential fractions. So at exercises, we will clearly indicate what needs to be done.</par>
